## Preference

- Preferences on a set $X$ are a function $f$ that assigns to any pair $(x, y)\in X$ exactly one of the three “values” $x \succ y$, $y \succ x$, or $I$ s.t. 
    - No order effect: $f(x,y)=f(y,x)$
    - Transitivity: if $f(x,y) = x \succ y$ and $f(y,z) = y \succ z$, then $f(x,z) = x \succ z$
- (Rational) Preferences on a set $X$ is a binary relation $\succsim$ s.t. for any $x, y\in X$:
    - Completeness: $x \succsim y$, or $y \succsim x$, or both
    - Transitivity: if $x \succsim y$ and $y \succsim z$, then $x \succsim z$

> HM1  
> Show that the two definitions of preferences are indeed equivalent.  

Intuition:

| 1st definition | 2nd definition                    |
| -------------- | --------------------------------- |
| $x \succ y$    | $x \succsim y$ and $\lnot y \succsim x$ |
| $I$            | $x \succsim y$ and $y \succsim x$ |
| $y \succ x$    | $y \succsim x$ and $\lnot x \succsim y$ |

Define $T$ as function of $f$ in definition 1:  
$$T(f) = \{ (x,y) \in X\times X \ | \ f(x,y) = x > y \text{or} f(x,y) = I\}$$

1. Check completeness  
:) for any $x$ and $y$, either $(x, y) \in T(f)$ or $(y, x) \in T(f)$  
2. Check transitivity  
:) if $(x, y) \in T(f)$ and $(y, z) \in T(f)$, then $(x, z) \in T(f)$  
$$\begin{cases} x>y \text{ and } y>z \implies x>z \\
x>y \text{ and } yIz \implies x>z \\
xIy \text{ and } y>z \implies x>z \\
xIy \text{ and } yIz \implies xIz \end{cases}$$ 
3. Check injection  
Let some $f^1\neq f^2$  
$\implies$ there are some $x, y$ s.t. $f^1(x, y)\neq f^2(x, y)$  
$\implies T(f^1)\neq T(f^2)$  
4. Check surjection  
Define $f^R$ s.t.  
$$f^R(x,y) = \begin{cases}  x>y & \text{if } (x,y) \in R \text{ and } (y,x) \not\in R \\
I & \text{if } (x,y), (y,x) \in R \\
y>x & \text{if } (x,y) \not\in R \text{ and } (y,x) \in R\end{cases}$$ 
Check $f^R$ is transitive  
Assume for some $x, y, z$, $f^R(x,y) = I$ and $f^R(y,z) = I$  
$\implies x\geq y$ and $y\geq x$, $y\geq z$ and $z\geq y$  
$\implies x\geq z$ and $z\geq x$  
$\implies xIz$

> HM2 (RBST PS1.Q2)  
> Consider a binary relation $P$ interpreted as "strictly preferred" s.t.  
> 1. Asymmetry: For no $x$ and $y$ do we have both $xPy$ and $yPx$  
> 2. Negative Transitivity: For all $x, y, z \in X$, if $xPy$, then either $xPz$ or $zPy$ (or both)  
> Explain why it is equivalent to the traditional definition.

Define $T$ as function of $P$ (strict preference):  
$$T(P) = \{ (x, y) \ | \ \lnot yPx \}$$

1. Check completeness  
FSOC assume $T(P)$ is not complete  
$\implies$ there are some $x, y$ s.t. $(\lnot xPy)$ and $(\lnot yPx)$  
$\implies xPy$ and $yPx$, contradicts to asymmetry  
2. Check transitivity  
FSOC assume $T(P)$ is not transitive  
$\implies$ there are some $x, y, z$ s.t. $xPy$ and $yPz$, but $(\lnot xPz)$  
$\implies (\lnot yPx)$, $(\lnot zPy)$ and $zPx$  
But $zPx \implies yPx$ or $zPy$, contradiction  
3. Check injection  
Let some $P^1 \neq P^2$  
$\implies$ there are some $(x, y) \in P^1$ but $(x, y) \not\in P^2$  
$\implies xP^1y$ and $\lnot xP^2y$  
$\implies (y,x) \not\in T(P^1)$ and $(y,x) \in T(P^2)$  
$\implies T(P^1)\neq T(P^2)$  
4. Check surjection  
Let some $R$ satisfy definition 2  
Define $P^R = \{ (x, y) \ | \ \lnot yRx \}$  
$$\begin{aligned}  T(P^R) &= \{ (x, y) \ | \ \lnot (y, x) \in P) \} \\
&= \{ (x, y) \ | \ \lnot ( \lnot yRx) \} \\
&= \{ (x, y) \ | \ xRy \}\end{aligned}$$ 

> HM3 (RBST PS1.Q4)  
> Let $\succ$ be an asymmetric binary relation on a finite set $X$ that does not have cycles.  
> Show that $\succ$ can be extended to a complete ordering (i.e. complete, asymmetric, and transitive)  
> Hint: induce on the size of $X$

1. Let $|X| = 1 \implies X = \{x\}$  
Since $\succ$ is asymmetric, $\lnot( x \succ x)$  
$\implies \succ^* = \succ$ is transitive and complete  
2. Assume $\succ$ can be extended to a complete and transitive ordering $\succ^*$ for $|X| = n$  
3. Let $|X| = n+1$  
Choose $x^* \in X$ s.t. $\lnot(x' \succ x^*)$ for all $x'\in X$  
$\implies \lnot (x \succ x^*)$ for all $x\in X\backslash x^*$  
Since $|X\backslash x^*| = n$  
$\implies \succ^*$ is complete for all $x\in X\backslash x^*$  
$\implies x \succ^* x' \lor x'\succ^* x$ for all $x, x'\in X\backslash x^*$  
Define $\succ^*$ for $x^*$ as $x^* \succ^* x$ for all $x\in X\backslash x^*$  
$\implies \succ^*$ is complete for all $x\in X$  
And, for all $x \succ^* x'\in X\backslash x^*$, $x^* \succ^* x$ and $x^* \succ^* x'$  
$\implies x^* \succ^* x \succ^* x'$  
$\implies \succ^*$ is transitive for all $x\in X$

### Utility Function

- Utility function $U: X\to \mathbb{R}$ represents the preference relation $\succsim$ if $x \succsim y \iff U(x)\geq U(y)$ 
- If $U$ represents $\succsim$, then for any strictly increasing $f$, $f\big( U(x)\big)$ also represents $\succsim$

### Continuity

- $\succsim$ on $X$ is continuous if $a\succsim b$ $\implies$ there exist balls $B_a$ and $B_b$ s.t. $a'\succsim b'$ for all $a' \in B_a$ and $b' \in B_b$
- Utility representation $U$ is continuous if $\succsim$ is continuous and $X$ is convex

> HM5.2  
> Can a continuous preference relation be represented by a discontinuous utility function?

Yes. See $U(x)$ in HM5.1

Take $x=1$, $y=\frac{1}{2}$  
$u(x) = 1$, $u(y) = 0$, $u(x) > u(y)$  
$\implies x\succ y$  
FSOC assume the preference induced by $u()$ is continuous

> PS0.Q1  
> 1. What does it mean for a preference relation to be continuous?  
> 2. Give an example of a preference relation that is not continuous.  
> 3. Explain why the preference in your example is not continuous.

1. A preference relation $\succsim$ is continuous if $a\succsim b$ $\implies$ there is $ε>0$ s.t. $B_ε(a)\succsim B_ε(b)$  
2. Lexicographic preference:  
$(a_1,a_2)\succsim_L (b_1,b_2)$ $\iff$ $a_1>b_1$ or $\begin{cases} a_1=b_1 \\ a_2\geq b_2 \end{cases}$  
3. If $\succsim_L$ is continuous, then exists continuous utility representaiton s.t. $B(a)\succsim_L B(b)$ for some neighbourhood $B(a)$ and $B(b)$, which is not the case.  

> PS0.Q2  
> Let $X$ be a finite set of alternatives.  
> For each pair $(x, y)$ we ask our decision maker to fill out the following questionnaire:  
> How do you compare $x$ and $y$? Tick one of the following five options:  
> $$\begin{aligned} x&\succ\succ y \\ x&\succ y \\ x&Iy \\ y&\succ x \\ y&\succ\succ x\end{aligned}$$ 
> Assume the answers of the decision are such that $\succ$ is a preference relation, and, moreover the following three conditions hold:  
> a) if $x\succ y$ or $xIy$ and $y\succ\succ z$, then $x\succ\succ z$  
> b) if $x\succ\succ y$ and $y\succ z$ or $yIz$, then $x\succ\succ z$  
> c) if $x\succ y$ and $y\succ z$, then $x\succ\succ z$  
> Show that there exists a function $u: X\to \mathbb{R}$ such that:  
> 1) $u(x)>u(y) \iff x\succ y$  
> 2) $u(x)>u(y)+1 \iff x\succ\succ y$  
> 3) $u(x)=u(y) \iff xIy$

Proof by mathematical induction:  
When $|X| = 1$, there exist $U(x) = 0$, for example, that $U(\cdot)$ satisfies (1) \~ (3)

Assume there is some utility function s.t. (1) \~ (3) are satisfied for $|X| = n$

Consider $|X| = n+1$:  
Since $|X\backslash\{x_1\}| = n$, exsits $U(\cdot)$ s.t. (1) \~ (3) are satisfied  
Denote the optimal element of $|X\backslash\{x_1\}|$ as $x_2$  
Extend $u$ as: $$u(x_1) = \begin{cases} U(x_2) + 2 & x_1\succ\succ x_2 \\
U(x_2) + 1 & x_1\succ x_2 \\
U(x_2) & x_1 I x_2 \\
U(x_2) - 1 & x_2\succ x_1 \\
U(x_2) - 2 & x_2\succ\succ x_1\end{cases}$$ 
Therefore, $U(\cdot)$ satisfies (1) \~ (3) for $|X| = n+1$ 

### Rational Choice Function

RBST P25, MWG 1.D

- $C_{\succsim}(\cdot)$ is the choice function induced by rational preference $\succsim$ that assigns the $\succsim$-best element of every $A\in D$
- $C_{\succsim}(\cdot)$ satisfies WARP

## Choice

- Choice Function $C(\cdot)$ is defined on: 
    - Context $(X,D)$: $X$ is the universe of all alternatives, 
    - Domain: $D$, a set of feasibly possible subsets of $X$, $D \subset 2^X$ (power set)
    - Choice structure: $(D, C(\cdot))$
- $C(\cdot)$: correspondence, assigns the best element(s) $C(A)\in A$ to every choice problem $A\in D$
    - If $x,y\in C(A)$, then $x$ is revealed to be at least as good as $y$
    - If $x\in C(A)$ and $y\not\in C(A)$, then $x$ is revealed to be strictly better than $y$

### Revealed Preference Relation

(MWG Definition 1.C.2)

- Given a choice function $C$ and domain $D$, Revealed Preference Relation $\succsim^*$ is defined as  
$x\succsim^* y\iff$ exists $B\in D$ s.t. $x,y\in B$ and $x\in C(B)$ 
    - $\succsim^*$ is not necessarily complete or transitive

### WARP (Weak Axiom of Revealed Preference)

(RBST P31, slide 4 P70, slide 6 P111)

- Choice $C$ satisfies WARP if for any $x,y\in A\cap B\in D$, $x\in C(A)$ and $y\in C(B)$ $\implies$ $x\in C(B)$ 
    - If $x$ is revealed to be at least as good as $y$, then $y$ is not revealed to be strictly better than $x$
- Condition α: if $a\in A\subset B$, and $a\in C(B)$, then $a\in C(A)$
    - WARP $\implies$ Condition α 
- Condition β: if $a,b\in A\subset B$, $a\in C(A)$, and $b\in C(B)$, then also $a\in C(B)$
    - WARP $\implies$ Condition β
- WARP $\iff$ Condition α $\iff$ Condition β if $A,B\in D\implies A\cap B\in D$ 

### SARP (Strong Axiom of Revealed Preference)

(slide 6 P113)

- Choice $C$ sattisfies SARP $\iff \succ_R$ is acyclical: there is no $x_1,x_2,\dots,x_k$ s.t. $x_1 \succ_R x_2 \succ_R\dots\succ_R x_k\succ_R x_1$

### Rationalizing Choice Function

- $C(\cdot)$ is rationalizable if there is a rational preference relation $\succsim$ on $X$ s.t. $C(A) = C_{\succsim}(A)$ for every $A\in D$
    - It is possible for some $C(\cdot)$ to be rationalized by multiple preference relations

> HM6, MWG Proposition 1.D.2  
> Assume that $C$ is a choice correspondence with a domain that includes at least all subsets of size 2 or 3.  
> Prove that if $C$ satisfies WA, then there is a preference $\succsim$ so that $C = C_{\succsim}$.

Define $x\succsim y$ if $x\in C\big(\{x,y\}\big)$

1. Completeness  
Since $C\big(\{x,y\}\big)\neq 0$, $\succsim$ is complete  
2. Transitivity  
Let $x\in C\big(\{x,y\}\big)$ and $y\in C\big(\{y,z\}\big)$  
Since by WA, $y\in C\big(\{x,y,z\}\big)$ $\implies$ $x\in C\big(\{x,y,z\}\big)$  
and $z\in C\big(\{x,y,z\}\big)$ $\implies$ $y\in C\big(\{x,y,z\}\big)$ $\implies$ $x\in C\big(\{x,y,z\}\big)$  
$\implies x\in C\big(\{x,y,z\}\big)$ always holds  
$\implies x\in C\big(\{x,z\}\big)$  
$\implies x\succsim z$

    1. Let $x\in C(A)$  
$\implies x\in C\big(\{x,y\}\big)$ for all $y\in A$  
$\implies x\succsim y$ for all $y\in A$  
$\implies x\in C_{\succsim}(A)$
    2. Let $x\in C_{\succsim}(A)$  
Let $y\in C(A)$ (? needs check)  
If $x\neq y\implies x\in C_{\succsim}(A)$  
$\implies x\in C(A)$

> PS0.Q4  
> Claire’s choice behavior is represented by a choice function $f: D \to X$, where $X = \{a, b, c, d, e\}$, and $D$ consists of all subsets of $X$ of size 3.  
> Assume:  
> $$\begin{aligned} f(\{a,b,c\}) &= a \\ f(\{b,c,d\}) &= b \\ f(\{c,d,e\}) &= c \\ f(\{a,d,e\}) &= d\end{aligned}$$ 
> 1. What does it mean that a choice function can be rationalized?  
> 2. Do the facts about $f$ imply that $f$ cannot be rationalized?  
> 3. Does $f$ satisfy the weak axiom of revealed preference?  
> 4. Does $f$ satisfy the strong axiom of revealed preference?  
> 5. What is the relationship between your answers to (2), (3), and (4)?

1. Choice function $C$ can be rationalized if exists preference relation $\succsim$ on $X$ s.t.  
for any $A\in D$, $C(A)$ is strictly better ($\succ$) than any other bundles in $A$  
2. Yes.  
$f(\{a,b,c\}) = a \implies a\succ b$  
$f(\{b,c,d\}) = b \implies b\succ c$ $\implies$ $a\succ c$  
$f(\{c,d,e\}) = c \implies c\succ d$ $\implies$ $a\succ d$  
$f(\{a,d,e\}) = d \implies d\succ a$, transitivity is violated.  
3. WARP: for any $x,y\in A\cap B\in D$, $x\in C(A)$ and $y\in C(B)$ $\implies$ $x\in C(B)$  
Since $A\cap B$ are all singletons, WARP is satisfied.  
4. SARP: $\succsim$ is acyclical (violated)  
5. Rationalizability $\implies$ SARP $\implies$ WARP 

## Demand (Consumer Preference)

- Preference relation $\succsim$ on $X$ satisfies: 
    - Rationality: Completeness + Transitivity 
    - Monotonic
    - Continuous: $x\succ y\implies x' \succ y'$ for all $d(x,x')<ε$ and $d(y,y')<ε$, for some $ε>0$ 
    - Convex
- __Monotonic + Continuous__ preference relations can be represented by a utility function

> PS0.Q6, RBST P50 Claim  
> John’s preferences over bundles $(x, y)\in [0, \infty)^2$ are monotonic and continuous.  
> Explain how one can construct a utility function representing John’s preferences.

For some bundle $(x,y)$,  
Since $(x,y)\succsim \mathbb{0} = (0,0)$,  
and $(x,y)\precsim M = \big(\max(x,y),\max(x,y)\big)$,  
Exists $(\hat{x},\hat{x})\in (\mathbb{0}, M)$ s.t. $(x,y)\sim (\hat{x},\hat{x})$  

By monotonicity and continuity, $(\hat{x},\hat{x})$ exists and is unique for every $(x,y)$,  
denoted as $\hat{x} = f(x,y)$  
Let $u(x,y) = f(x,y)$  
For any $(x',y')$, $(x,y)\succsim (x',y')$ $\iff$ 
$$\begin{aligned} \hat{x} &\succsim \hat{x}' \\
u(x,y) &\geq u(x',y')\end{aligned}$$

1. Since the monkey always spends $\frac{1}{3}$ of his wealth on apples and $\frac{2}{3}$ on bananas,

When $m = 4$, $a = 2$, $b = 100$, the monkey chooses $(8,0)\succsim (4, 200)\succ (4,6)$

Contradiction. 

### Continuity (revisited)

- If $\succsim$ on $X$ is continuous, then exists a utility function $u(x)$ that represents $\succsim$
    - $u(x)$ is continuous

### Monotonicity

- Locally Nonsatiation
- (Weak) Monotonicity: if $x_k > y_k$ for all $k$, then $x\succ y$
- Strong Monotonicity: if $x_k\geq y_k$ for all $k$ and $x\neq y$, then $x\succ y$
    - __Monotonic + Continuous__ preference relation is represented by __Increasing__ utility function

### Convexity

- Convexity: $x\succsim y\implies$ $λx + (1-λ)y\succsim y$, for all $λ\in (0,1)$ 
- Strict convexity: $x, x'\succsim y\implies$ $λx + (1-λ)x'\succ y$, for all $λ\in (0,1)$ 
    - __Convex + Monotonic + Continuous__ preference relation is represented by __Quasi-concave__ utility function

### Special Preferences

Preference that can be induced by one single indifference set

- Indifference Set: $\{ y\in X \ | \ y\sim x\}$
- Homothetic Preference:  
$x\succsim y\implies αx\succsim αy$ for all $α\geq 0$
    - __Homothetic + Monotonic + Continuous__ preference relations can be represented by __Continuous + Homogeneous (1)__ utility function 
- Quasi-Linear Preference  
$x\succsim y\implies (x+εe_1)\succsim (y+εe_1)$ for all $ε\geq 0$, $e_1 = (1,0,\dots,0)$ 
    - __Quasi-Linear + Strong Monotonic + Continuous__ preference relations can be represented by $U = x_1 + v(x_2,\dots,x_K)$ for some $v$ 
- Leontief Preference  
$x\succsim y\iff \min\{x_1,x_2\}\geq\min\{y_1,y_2\}$ 
    - Monotonic + Continuous but not differentiable

### UMP (Utility Maximization Problem)

- Commodity Space: $\mathbb{R}^K_+$
    - Convex
- Consumption Set: $X \subset \mathbb{R}^K_+$ $=$ $\big\{ x = (x_1, x_2,\dots, x_K) \ | \ x_k\geq 0 \big\}$ 
    - Assumed to be Convex (not necessarily)
- Consumption Bundle: $x = (x_1, x_2,\dots, x_K) \in X$ 
    - $x_k$ represents the quantity of commodity $k$ 
- Price Vector: $p = (p_1, p_2,\dots, p_K) \in \mathbb{R}^K$

~

- Utility Maximization Problem: 
$$\begin{aligned} \max_x u(x) && \text{s.t.} && p\cdot x\leq w\end{aligned}$$ 
    - If $p\gg 0$ and $u(\cdot)$ is continuous, then UMP has a solution
- (Marshallian / Walrasian) Demand Correspondence: $x(p,w)$
    - Demand Function when single-valued
    - $\succsim$ is __Monotonic + Continuous__ $\implies x(p,w)$ is __Homogeneous (0) + Walras Law__  
    $\succsim$ is convex $\implies x(p,w)$ is convex  
    $\succsim$ is strictly convex $\implies x(p,w)$ is single-valued
    $\succsim$ is __Continuous + Strictly Convex + Monotonic__ $\implies x(p,w)$ is continuous

### Indirect Preference & Utility

RBST P78, slide 7 P121, MWG Proposition 3.D.3

- Indirect Preference: $\succsim^*$ induced by $\succsim$
    - $(p,w)\succsim^* (p',w')$ if $x(p,w)\succsim x(p',w')$ 
    - Invariance to Presentation: $(λ\cdot p,λ\cdot w) \sim^* (p,w)$ for all $λ>0$ 
    - Monotonicity: $\succsim^*$ is weakly decreasing in $p_k$ and strictly increasing in $w$ 
    - Continuity
- Indirect Utility Function: $v(p,w) = u(x^*)$ for all $(p,w)\in\mathbb{R}^{K+1}_{++}$
    - When $\succsim$ is __Monotonic + Continuous__
    - Homogeneous (0)
    - Strictly Increasing in $w$, non-decreasing in $p_k$ for all $k$
    - Continuous in $p,w$
    - Quasi-convex

### Differentiability

(slide 5 P86)

- Improvement: $z\in\mathbb{R}^K$ s.t. $x + z\succ x$
    - Improvement Direction: $d\in\mathbb{R}^K$ s.t. $x + λd\succ x$ for all $λ\in (0,\exists λ^*)$
    - Set of Improvement Directions at $x$: $d\in D_{\succsim}(x)$ $\implies$ $λd\in D_{\succsim}(x)$
- Subjective value function: $x+d\succ x \iff v(x)^T\cdot d >0$
- $\succsim$ is differentiable at $x$ if exists $v(x)\in\mathbb{R}^K_+$ s.t. $D_{\succsim}(x) = D_{v(x)}(x)$
    - If $\succsim$ is represented by $u(x)$: __differentiable + quasi-concave__, then $\succsim$ is differentiable with 
    $$\begin{aligned} v(x) &= \nabla u(x) \\
    &= \bigg(\frac{\partial u(x)}{\partial x_1}, \frac{\partial u(x)}{\partial x_2},\dots, \frac{\partial u(x)}{\partial x_K} \bigg) \ \text{(MWG P53)}\end{aligned}$$
    - Marginal Utility: 
    $$\begin{aligned} v_k(x^*) &= \frac{\partial u(x^*)}{\partial x_k} \\ &= MU_k\end{aligned}$$

> PS0.Q3  
> Consider a world with 2 commodities.  
> 1. What does it mean for a preference to be differentiable?  
> 2. Show that the preferences induced by utility function $u\big((x, y)\big) = \min(x, y)$ are not differentiable.

1. Preferences are differentiable at bundle $x$ if there is a vector $v(x)$ of K non-negative numbers s.t. the set of improvement directions coincides with $\{d\in \mathbb{R}^K \ | \ d\cdot v(x) > 0\}$  
Preferences are differentiable if they are differentiable at any bundle $x$  
2. FSOC assume $u\big((x, y)\big) = \min(x, y)$ is differentiable at $(x,y)=(0,0)$  
Since $(1,0)$ and $(0,1)$ are not improvement directions,  
$$\begin{cases} (1,0)\cdot v\leq 0 \\ (0,1)\cdot v\leq 0\end{cases}$$ 
but $(1,1)$ is improvement direction, so  
$$\begin{aligned} (1,0) + (0,1) &= (1,1) \\ (1,1) \cdot v &> 0\end{aligned}$$ 
Contradiction.

### Consumer Problem with Differentiable Preference

slide 6 P97, RBST P65

- If $\succsim$ is differentiable with $v(x)$, $x^*$ is a solution to the consumer problem, $x^*_k > 0$, then $\frac{v_k(x^*)}{p_k}\geq \frac{v_j(x^*)}{p_j}$ for all $j\neq k$
    - When $x^*_j = 0$, $\frac{v_k(x^*)}{p_k} > \frac{v_j(x^*)}{p_j}$ ($x^*$ is boundary solution, see HM8) 
    - When $x^*_j > 0$, 
    $$\begin{aligned} \frac{v_k(x^*)}{p_k} &= \frac{v_j(x^*)}{p_j} \\
    \frac{v_k(x^*)}{v_j(x^*)} &= \frac{p_k}{p_j} \\
    \frac{\partial u(x^*) / \partial x_k}{\partial u(x^*) / \partial x_j} &= \frac{p_k}{p_j} \\
    \underbrace{\frac{MU_k}{MU_j}}_{\text{MRS of k for j}} &= \frac{p_k}{p_j}\end{aligned}$$

### EMP (Expenditure Minimizationg Problem)

- Expenditure Minimizationg Problem:  
$$\begin{aligned} \min_x p\cdot x && \text{s.t.} && u(x)\geq \bar{u}\end{aligned}$$
- Expenditure Function: $e(p,u) = p\cdot x^*$
    - If $\succsim$ is __monotonic + continuous__, then:
    - Homogeneous (1)
    - Strictly increasing in $u$, non-decreasing in $p_k$ for all $k$
    - Concave in $p$
    - Continuous in $p,u$ 
- Hicksian Demand Correspondence: $h(p,u)\subset\mathbb{R}^K_+$
    - Hicksian Demand Function when single-valued
    - Homogeneous (0) in $p$: $h(p,u) = h(αp,u)$ for all $α>0$
    - No Excess Utility: $u(x) = \bar{u}$ for all $x\in h(p,\bar{u})$ (as compared to Walras Law)
    - Satisfies [Compensated Law of Demand](#compensated-law-of-demand): $(p'-p)\cdot \big(h(p',\bar{u}) - h(p,\bar{u})\big)\leq 0$  
    $\iff$ Non-increasing in $p_k$
    - $\succsim$ is convex $\implies x^*$ is convex  
    $\succsim$ is strictly convex $\implies x^*$ is singleton 
    - Roy's Identity:  
    $$\begin{aligned} x(p^*,w^*) &= -\frac{\nabla_p v(p^*, w^*)}{\nabla_w v(p^*,w^*)} \\
    x_k(p^*,w^*) &= -\frac{\partial v(p^*, w^*) / \partial p_k}{\partial v(p^*, w^*) / \partial w}\end{aligned}$$ 

### Dual Consumer

- For price vector $p$ and initial bundle (endowment) $z$,
- Prime Problem $P(p,z)$, UMP:  
Find the $\succsim$-best bundle $x(p,z)$ (__Marshallian / Walrasian demand function__) s.t.  
$$\begin{aligned} \max_x u(x) && \text{s.t.} && p\cdot x\leq p\cdot z\end{aligned}$$ 
- Dual Problem $D(p,z)$, EMP:  
Find the cheapest bundle $h(p,\bar{u})$ (__Hicksian demand function__) s.t.  
$$\begin{aligned} \min_x p\cdot x && \text{s.t.} && u(x)\geq\bar{u} = u(z) \end{aligned}$$ 
    - Expenditure function: $e(p,\bar{u}) = p\cdot h(p,\bar{u})$
- UMP and EMP are equivalent  
if $u(x)$ is __Increasing + Continuous__ $\iff\succsim$ is __Monotonic + Continuous__
    - UMP $\implies$ EMP if $u(x)$ is increasing
    - EMP $\implies$ UMP if $u(x)$ is continuous

### Duality Properties

(RBST P82, slide 7 P132)

- If $\bar{u} = u\big( x(p,w)\big)$, then $h(p,\bar{u}) = x(p,w)$ 
- $h(p,\bar{u}) = h(λp,\bar{u})$ and $e(λp,\bar{u}) = λe(p,\bar{u})$ 
- $h(p,\bar{u}) \sim z$ 
- $h(p,\bar{u})$ and $e(p,\bar{u})$ are continuous 
- $H = \big\{(p,e) \ | \ e = p\cdot h(p^*, \bar{u})\big\}$ is tangent to $e(p,\bar{u})$ at $p^*$ 
- MWG Proposition 3.G.1:  
$$\begin{aligned} h( p^*, \bar{u}) &= \nabla_p e(p,\bar{u}) \\
h_k( p^*, \bar{u}) &= \frac{\partial e(p,\bar{u})}{\partial p_k}\end{aligned}$$ 
- Slutsky Equation: for all $(p,w)$ and $\bar{u} = v(p,w)$,  
$$\frac{\partial h_k(p,\bar{u})}{\partial p_k} = \frac{\partial x_k(p,w)}{\partial p_k} + \frac{\partial x_k(p,w)}{\partial w}\cdot x_k(p,w)$$

- Let $\begin{cases} u = v(p, w) \\ u' = v(p',w)\end{cases}$, $e(p,u) = e(p',u') = w$ (Walras Law)

$$\begin{aligned}u &= v(p', w - CV) \\ e(p,u) &= e\big( p', v(p',w - CV)\big) \\ &= w - CV\end{aligned}$$

## Demand (Consumer Choice)

### Consumer Problem

- (Walras) Budget Set: $B(p,w) = \{x\in X \ | \ p\cdot x\leq w\}$ 
    - Non-empty 
    - Compact 
    - Convex (if $X$ is convex) 
- Budget Line (Hyperplane): $\{x\in X \ | \ p\cdot x = w\}$ 
    - Rate of Exchange: $-\frac{p_1}{p_2}$ (when $K = 2$)
- Consumer problem: find the $\succsim$-best bundle in $B(p,w)$ 
    - Solution: $x^*$ s.t. $x^*\succsim x$ for all $x\in B(p,w)$ 
    - $\succsim$ is continuous $\implies x^*$ exists  
    $\succsim$ is convex $\implies x^*$ is convex  
    $\succsim$ is strictly convex $\implies x^*$ is singleton  

### Demand Function

- Choice Structure: $\big( B, x(\cdot)\big)$
- (Marshallian / Walrasian) Demand Correspondence: $x(p,w)$
    - (Walrasian) Demand Function when single-valued
    - If $\succsim$ is __Continuous + Monotonic__, then:
    - Homogeneous (0): $x(p,w) = x(λp, λw)$ for all $λ>0$ 
    - __Walras Law__: $p\cdot x(p,w) = w$ (if $\succsim$ is monotonic) 
    - Convex ($\succsim$ is convex)
    - Single-valued + Continuous ($\succsim$ is strictly convex)

### WARP (revisited)

- If $x(p,w)\neq x(p',w')$, then  
$$\begin{aligned} &\phantom{\implies}\begin{cases}x(p',w')\in B(p,w) & \text{(not chosen)}\\ p\cdot x(p',w')\leq w & \text{(feasible)}\end{cases} \\
&\implies \\
&\phantom{\implies}\begin{cases} x(p,w)\not\in B(p',w') \\ p'\cdot x(p,w) > w' & \text{(infeasible)}\end{cases}\end{aligned}$$ 
    - $x(p,w)\succsim^* x(p',w')$

![RBST Figure 5.2(a)](/post-img/notes-micro--demand-warp.png)

> MWG Exercise 2.F.2  
> In a three-commodity world, let $w = 8$, consider three budget sets and respective (unique) choices:

> Verify that any two pairs of choices satisfy the WA,

> which is incompatible with the existence of underlying rational preferences (violates transitivity)

$x_1\in B(p_2, w)$, $x_2\notin B(p_1, w)\implies x_2\succsim^* x_1$  
$x_2\in B(p_3, w)$, $x_3\notin B(p_2, w)\implies x_3\succsim^* x_2$  
$x_3\in B(p_1, w)$, $x_1\notin B(p_3, w)\implies x_1\succsim^* x_3$  
$\implies x_1\succsim^* x_3\succsim^* x_2\succsim^* x_1$, transitivity is violated

slide 6 P106, RBST P68

- $\succsim$ fully rationalizes $x(p,w)$ if $x(p,w)$ is the unique $\succsim$-best bundle in $B(p,w)$

### SARP (revisited)

- For any $(p^1,w^1)$, $(p^2,w^2)$, ... $(p^N,w^N)$,  
with $x(p^n, w^n)\neq x(p^{n+1}, w^{n+1})$, then  
$$\begin{aligned} &p^n\cdot x(p^{n+1},w^{n+1})\leq w^n\text{ for all }n\leq N-1 \\
\implies &p^N\cdot x(p^1,w^1)>w^N\end{aligned}$$
- If $x(p,w)$ satisfies SARP, then exists $\succsim$ that rationalizes $x(p,w)$

### Types of Commodity

- Normal: $\begin{cases}\frac{\partial x_k(p,w)}{\partial w}\geq 0 \\ \frac{\partial x_k(p,w)}{\partial p_k} \leq 0 \end{cases}$
    - Inferior: $\frac{\partial x_k(p,w)}{\partial w} < 0$
    - Giffen: $\frac{\partial x_k(p,w)}{\partial p_k} > 0$

### (Compensated) Law of Demand

- For a compensated price change, demand and price move in opposite directions
- Let $x(p,w)$ be homogeneous and satisfy Walras Law  
- If $w' = p'\cdot x(p,w)$, then for $p' > p$, $x(p,w)$ satisfy WARP $\iff$  
$$\begin{aligned} &\phantom{\ggg}(p' - p)\cdot \big(x(p',w') - x(p,w)\big) \\
&= \underbrace{p'\cdot x(p',w')}_{\text{Walras Law}} - \underbrace{p'\cdot x(p,w)}_{\text{Compensated wealth}} - p\cdot x(p',w') + p\cdot x(p,w)\\
&= w' - w' - p\cdot x(p',w') + w \\
&= w - \underbrace{p \cdot x(p',w')}_{\text{WARP: infeasible}} \\
&\leq 0\end{aligned}$$ 
    - Slutsky Wealth Compensation: s.t. the original bundle is feasible 
    $$\begin{aligned} Δw &= (p' - p)\cdot x(p,w) \\ w' &= (p' - p)\cdot x(p,w) + w \\ &= p'\cdot x(p,w)\end{aligned}$$ 
    <!-- - Intuition: an increase in price makes the consumer poorer than before (impoverish) -->
    - Equality holds only when $x(p',w') = x(p,w)$

- Slutsky Substitution Matrix: $S(p,w)$ ($K\times K$)  
$$\begin{aligned} s_{k,l} &= \frac{\partial x_k(p,w)}{\partial p_k} + \frac{\partial x_k(p,w)}{\partial w}\cdot x_l(p,w) \\
s_{k,k} &\leq 0\end{aligned}$$

## Producer

### Technology

- Commodities: $1, 2,\dots, K$ 
- Production Combination: $y\in \mathbb{R}^K$, positive: output, negative: input 
- Technology Space: $Y \subset \mathbb{R}^K$ of all feasible $y$'s 
    - Closed and convex $\implies$ decreasing marginal productivity  
    $\implies$ non-increasing returns to scale
    - No production with zero resources
    - Free disposal

### Production Function

- Output: $q$ (commodity $K$)
- Inputs: $z = (z_1, z_2, \dots,z_{K-1})$ (commodities $1, 2,\dots, K-1$)
- Production Function: $f(z): \mathbb{R}^{K-1}\to\mathbb{R}$  
$$f(z) = \max\{ q \ | \ (-z,q)\in Y \}$$
    - Continuous
    - Strictly Increasing
    - $f(0) = 0$

<!-- $f(z)$ defines the Technology Space as $$Y = \{(-z, q) \ | \ f(z)\geq q, z\geq 0\}$$ -->

### PMP (Profit Maximization Problem)

- Profit Maximization Problem:  
$$\begin{aligned}\max_y p\cdot y && \text{s.t.} && y\in Y\end{aligned}$$
- Profit Function: $$π(p) = \max\{p\cdot y \ | \ y\in Y\}$$
    - Homogeneous (1)
    - Continuous
    - Convex
- Supply Correspondence (Net Supply): $$y(p) = \{y\in Y \ | \ p\cdot y = π(p)\}$$
    - Homogeneous (0)
    - Continuous
    - $Y$ is convex $\implies y(p)$ is convex  
    $Y$ is strictly convex $\implies y(p)$ is single-valued
<!--
    - $π(p) \geq p\cdot z(p^*)$ for all $p$ and $p^*$ 
-->
    - Hotelling’s lemma: $π(p)$ is differentiable, and $\frac{\partial π}{\partial p_k}(p^*) = y_k(p^*)$  
    If $π(p)$ is twice differentiable, then $\frac{\partial y_j}{\partial p_k}(p^*) = \frac{\partial y_k}{\partial p_j}(p^*)$ 

> PS0.Q10  
> Assume that the producer’s problem always has a unique solution.  
> Prove that the profit function is convex.

Let $y(p)$ be the supply function  
The the profits function is given by $π(p) = p\cdot y(p)$  
For any price $p^*$, $π(p^*) = p^*\cdot y(p^*)$  
$\implies$ $\{(x,y) \ | \ p\cdot (x,y) = p\cdot y(p^*)\}$ is a hyperplane tangent to profit function at $p^*$  
And $π(p) \geq p\cdot y(p^*)$ for all $p$  
$\implies$ production function is convex

### Law of Supply 

- For all $p$, $p'$, $y\in y(p)$ and $y'\in y(p')$,  
$$\begin{aligned} &\phantom{\ggg}(p - p')\cdot(y - y') \\
&= p\cdot y - p\cdot y' - p'\cdot y + p'\cdot y' \\
&= (p\cdot y - p\cdot y') + (p'\cdot y' - p'\cdot y) \\
&= \big(\max_p p\cdot y(p) - p\cdot y'\big) + \big(\max_{p'} p'\cdot y(p') - p'\cdot y\big) \\
&\geq 0\end{aligned}$$

<!-- ![Source: [Investopedia](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/l/lawofsupply.asp)](/post-img/notes-micro--law-of-supply.png) -->

### CMP (Cost Minimization Problem)

- Input Price Vector: $w\geq 0$
- Cost Minimization Problem:  
$$\begin{aligned} \min_z w\cdot z && \text{s.t.} && f(z)\geq q\end{aligned}$$
    - Homogeneous (1)
    - Non-decreasing in $q$
    - Concave in $w$
- (Conditional) Factor Demand Correspondence: $z(w,q)$
    - Homogeneous (0) in $w$
    - $\{z\geq 0 \ | \ f(z)\geq q\}$ is convex $\implies z(w,q)$ is convex  
    $\{z\geq 0 \ | \ f(z)\geq q\}$ is strictly convex $\implies z(w,q)$ is single-valued
- Cost Function:  
$$c(w,q) = w\cdot z(w,q)$$
    - $f(\cdot)$ is concave $\implies c(w,q)$ is convex in $q$
    - Shephard's Lemma: if $z(w_0, q)$ is singleton, then $\frac{\partial c(w_0, q)}{\partial w_0} = z(w_0, q)$
- PMP becomes  
$$\max_{q} p\cdot q - c(w,q)$$

## Partial Equilibrium

AMT 4.1, slide 10 P4

- Set of consumers: $\mathcal{I}\equiv\{1,2,\dots, I\}$ 
- Individual $i$'s demand for good $q$ ($k$):  
$$q^i(p_k, \ p_{-k}, \ y^i)$$ 
    - Price of good $q$: $p_k$
    - Price of all other goods:  $p_{-k}$
    - Income: $y^i$
- Market demand:  
$$q^D(p)\equiv\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}} q^i(p_k, \ p_{-k}, \ y^i)$$ 

### Perfect Competition (Short Run)

- Settings: 
    - Output: $q$ (commodity $K$)
    - Input: $z$ (commodities $1,2,\dots,K-1$)
    - Price of Input: $w$
    - Price of Output: $p$
    - Set of firms: $\mathcal{J}\equiv\{1,2,\dots, J\}$ 
- Firm $j$'s supply for good $q$: $q^j(p, w)$ 
- Market supply: $$q^S(p)\equiv\sum_{j\in\mathcal{J}} q^j(p, w)$$ 
- SR Equilibrium at price $p^*$: $$q^D(p^*) = q^S(p^*)$$

### Perfect Competition (Long Run)

- Firms have free entry and exit: changing $J$
- Profit function:  
$$\begin{aligned} π(p, w) = \max_{p,w} p\cdot q - w\cdot z&& \text{s.t.} && f(z)\geq q\end{aligned}$$
    - increasing in $p$, decreasing in $\mathbb{w}$
    - homogenous of degree 1 in $(p, \mathbb{w})$
    - convex
    - differentiable for $(p, \mathbb{w})\gg 0$
    - Production function: $f(\mathbb{x})$
    - Hotelling's Lemma: $\begin{cases}\text{Output: } q(p,\mathbb{w}) = \frac{\partial π}{\partial p} \\\text{Input: }\phantom{\leq} z_i(p,\mathbb{w}) = -\frac{\partial π}{\partial w_i}\end{cases}$ 
- LR Equilibrium: $$\begin{cases} q^D(\hat{p}) = \sum_{j=1}^{\hat{J}} q^j(\hat{p}) \\ π^j(\hat{p}) = 0\end{cases}$$ 

### Monopoly

- Firm's problem: $$π(q) = \max_q \underbrace{p(q)\cdot q}_{r(q)} - c(q)$$
    - Optimal output: $q^*$
    - FOC:  $$\begin{aligned} MC(q^*) &= MR(q^*) \geq 0 \\ &= p(q)\cdot 1 + q\cdot\frac{dp(q)}{dq} \\
&= p(q) + \frac{dp(q)}{dq}\cdot\frac{q}{p(q)}\cdot p(q) \\
&= p(q)\cdot\Big(1+\frac{dp(q)}{dq}\cdot\frac{q}{p(q)}\Big) \\
&= p(q)\cdot\Big(1-\frac{1}{|\underbrace{ε(q)}_{\text{Elasticity}}|}\Big)\end{aligned}$$ 
- Monopoly Equilibrium: $$\frac{p(q^*) - MC(q^*)}{p(q^*)} = \frac{1}{|ε(q^*)|}$$

### Cournot (Quantity)

- Firms' problem: $$\max_{q^j} π^j(q^1,q^2,\dots,q^J) = \big(\underbrace{a-\overbrace{b\cdot\sum_J q^j}^{\text{Market Demand}}}_{\text{Market Price}}\big)\cdot q^j - c\cdot q^j$$ 
    - $\frac{\partial π^j}{\partial q^k}<0$ for all $j\neq k$ 
    - FOC: $$\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial π^j}{\partial q^j} &= a - 2bq^j - b\cdot\sum_{k\neq j} q^k - c \\
&= a - c - b\cdot\sum_{J} q^j - bq^j\end{aligned}$$
In equilibrium, let $q^1 = q^2 = \dots = \bar{q}$,  
$$\bar{q}= \frac{a-c}{b(J+1)}$$ 
- Cournot-Nash Equilibrium: $(\underbrace{\bar{q},\bar{q},\dots,\bar{q}}_{J})$

> A firm $j$ in a competitive industry has total cost function $c_j(q) = aq+b_jq^2$,

> 1. If $b_j > 0$ for all firms, what governs the amount produced by each of them? Will they produce equal amounts of output? Explain.

1. For each firm $j$:

p &= a + 2b_j\cdot q^* \\

When $b_j>0$, $p = a + 2b_j\cdot q_j > a$,  
therefore, the higher $b_j$ is, the lower $q_j$ is.  
They will not produce equal amounts of output.

> PS1.Q2, AMT Exercise 4.8  
> In the Cournot oligopoly, suppose that $J = 2$  
> Let each duopolist have constant average and marginal costs as before, but suppose that $0\leq c_1 < c_2$  
> Show that firm 1 will have greater profits and produce a greater share of market output than firm 2 in the Nash equilibrium.

For each firm: 
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{q^i} && π_i(q^1,q^2) = \big(a-b(q_1+q_2)\big)q_i - c_iq_i\end{aligned}$$ 
FOC:
$$\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial π_i}{\partial q_i} &= a - 2bq_i - bq_{-i} - c_i \\
q_i^* &= \frac{a - bq_{-i} - c_i}{2b} \\
&= \frac{a-c_i}{2b} - \frac{q_{-i}}{2}\end{aligned}$$ 
Therefore, 
$$\begin{cases} q_1^* =\frac{a-c_1}{2b} - \frac{q_{2}}{2} \\ q_2^* =\frac{a-c_2}{2b} - \frac{q_{1}}{2}\end{cases}$$ 
$$\implies\begin{cases} q_1^* =\frac{a-2c_1+c_2}{3b} \\ q_2^* =\frac{a-2c_2+c_1}{3b}\end{cases}$$ 
$c_2>c_1\implies q_1 > q_2$  
Consider profit: 
$$\begin{aligned} π_1(q^1,q^2) &= \big(a-b(q_1+q_2)\big)q_1 - c_1q_1 \\
&= \left(a - b\Big(\frac{a-2c_1+c_2}{3b} + \frac{a-2c_2+c_1}{3b}\Big)\right) q_1 - c_1q_1 \\
&= \Big( a - \frac{2a - c_1 - c_2}{3}\Big)q_1 - c_1q_1 \\
&= \frac{q_1}{3}(a-2c_1 + c_2) \\
\text{and } π_2(q^1,q^2) &= \frac{q_2}{3}(a-2c_2 + c_1)\end{aligned}$$ 
$c_2>c_1\implies π_1 > π_2$

### Bertrand Duopoly (Price)

- Firms' problem: $π^i = \begin{cases} (p^i - c)(α - βp^i) & p^i < p^{-i} \\ \frac{1}{2}(p^i - c)(α - βp^i) & p^i = p^{-i} \\ 0 & p^i > p^{-i}\end{cases}$ 
- Bertrand-Nash Equilibrium: $\begin{cases} p^i = c \\ π^i = 0\end{cases}$

### Total Welfare (Partial)

MWG (3.I.8), AMT (4.27), [#Consumer Welfare](#consumer-welfare)

- Assume initial market result: $(p^0,q^0)$, $p^0 > mc(q^0)$
- When $p_k$ changes, change of (Marshallian) Consumer Surplus:  
$$\begin{aligned} ΔCS &= CS(p',w) - CS(p,w) \\
&= \int_{p_k'}^{p_k} x_k(p,w) dp\end{aligned}$$
- With a movement to $(p^1,q^1)$:
    - Consumer Surplus: $ΔCS \approx CV = A + B$
    - Producer Surplus: $ΔPS \approx (E + F + C + D) - (A + E + F) = C + D - A$
    - Total Surplus: $ΔTS \approx (A + B) + (C + D - A) = B + C + D > 0$
    - Therefore, taking $A$ from the consumer to the producer will be a Pareto Improvement
- Move to $(p^2,q^2)$, ..., $(p^n,q^n)$ s.t. $p^n = mc(q^n)$ will be Pareto Improvements
- Pareto Efficient Outcome: $p = mc(q)$

## General Equilibrium (Exchange)

- Economy: $\mathcal{E}=(\succsim^i, e^i)_{i\in\mathcal{I}}$ 
    - Set of consumers: $\mathcal{I}\equiv\{1,2,\dots, I\}$ 
    - Consumer i's endowment: $e^i = (e^i_1, e^i_2,\dots, e^i_K)$ 
- Allocation for all goods: $x = (x^1,x^2,\dots,x^I)$ 
    - Feasible Allocations: $F(e)\equiv \big\{x \ | \ \sum_{\mathcal{I}} x^i = \sum_{\mathcal{I}} e^i\big\}$ 
    - Pareto Efficient Allocation: $x\in F(e)$ is Pareto efficient if there is no $y\neq x$ s.t. $y^i\succsim^i x^i$ for all $i\in \mathcal{I}$ and $y^i\succ^i x^i$ for at least one i

### Core

- Coalition of consumers: $S\subset \mathcal{I}$ 
- $S$ is a blocking coalition for $x\in F(e)$ if exists $y\neq x$ s.t. 
    - $\sum_S y^i = \sum_S e^i$
    - $y^i\succsim^i x^i$ for all $i\in S$ and $y^i\succ^i x^i$ for at least one i
- Core $C(e)$ is the set of all unblocked feasible allocations

### Efficiency & Edgeworth Box

- Contract Curve: Pareto efficient allocations
- Core $C(e)$: on the contract curve + inside the lens (not blocked by either consumer)

![Source: [Diagram Technology Templates and Examples](https://diagram-ideas.com/page/3082/)](/post-img/notes-micro--edgeworth-core.png)

### Competitive Market Equilibrium

- Market price: $p = (p_1, p_2,\dots,p_K)$ 
- Consumer's problem: $$\begin{aligned} \max u^i(x^i) && p\cdot x^i\leq p\cdot e^i\end{aligned}$$ 
    - AMT Assumption 5.1: 
    - Continuous
    - Strongly Increasing
    - Strictly Quasi-Concave
- Demanded bundle: $x^i(p,p\cdot e^i)$ 
    - Unique
    - Continuous in $p\in\mathbb{R}_{++}^K$
- Aggregate Excess Demand for good k  
$$z_k(p) = \sum_{\mathcal{I}}x^i_k(p,p\cdot e^i) - \sum_{\mathcal{I}} e^i_k$$ 
- Aggregate excess demand vector  
$$z(p) = \big(z_1(p), z_2(p),\dots, z_K(p)\big)$$
    - Condition: Assumption 5.1 $\implies$
    - Continuous in $p\in\mathbb{R}_{++}^K$
    - Homogeneous (0)
    - Walras' law: $p\cdot z(p) = 0$
- Walrasian Equilibrium (price): 
$$\begin{aligned} p^*\in\mathbb{R}_{++}^K && \text{s.t.} && z(p^*) = 0\end{aligned}$$
    - Conditions: Assumption 5.1 + $\sum_\mathcal{I} e^i \gg 0\implies$
    - $z(\cdot)$ is continuous
    - $p\cdot z(p) = 0$ for all $p\in\mathbb{R}_{++}^K$
- Walras Equilibrium Allocations (WEA)  
$$x(p^*) = (x^1(p^*,p^*\cdot e^1), \dots, x^n(p^*,p^*\cdot e^n))$$
    - $x(p^*)\in F(e)$
    - $u^i(x')\geq u^i\big(x^i(p^*)\big)$ $\implies$ $p\cdot x'\geq p\cdot \big(x^i(p^*)\big)$
- Set of WEAs: $W(e)\subset C(e)$  
    - Condition: $u^i$ strictly increasing

> PS2.Q1  
> Consider a two person economy where 2 consumers have CES (constant elasticity of substitution) utility functions: $u^i(x_1,x_2) = (x_1^ρ+x_2^ρ)^{\frac{1}{ρ}}$, $0<ρ<1$  
> and endowments $e^1 = (1,0)$, $e^2 = (0,1)$  
> Suppose there are given prices $p_1$ and $p_2$ for the two goods  
> Suppose further that consumers think their income is $y_1$ and $y_2$ (for the time being, not thinking about how they get that income)  
> Derive the consumers' demand functions for good 1 and good 2, respectively.

Let $p = (p_1,p_2)$, consumer's problem: 
$$\begin{aligned} \max_{x_1,x_2} u^i(x_1,x_2) = (x_1^ρ+x_2^ρ)^{\frac{1}{ρ}} \\ s.t. y^i = p_1x_1+p_2x_2 \\
\mathcal{L} = (x_1^ρ+x_2^ρ)^{\frac{1}{ρ}} - λ(p_1x_1+p_2x_2- y^i)\end{aligned}$$ 
FOC: 
$$\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial x_1} = \frac{1}{ρ}(x_1^ρ+x_2^ρ)^{\frac{1}{ρ}-1}\cdot ρx_1^{ρ-1} &- λp_1 = 0 \\
\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial x_2} = \frac{1}{ρ}(x_1^ρ+x_2^ρ)^{\frac{1}{ρ}-1}\cdot ρx_2^{ρ-1} &- λp_2 = 0 \\
\frac{x_1^{ρ-1}}{p_1} &= \frac{x_2^{ρ-1}}{p_2} \\
x_1 &= x_2\cdot\frac{p_1}{p_2}^{\frac{1}{ρ-1}}\end{aligned}$$ 
Substitution into constraint gives 
$$\begin{aligned} x_1^i = \frac{p_1^{r-1}}{p_1^r+p_2^r}y^i \\
x_2^i = \frac{p_2^{r-1}}{p_1^r+p_2^r}y^i\end{aligned}$$ 
where $r = \frac{ρ}{ρ-1}$ 

> PS2.Q2  
> Consider a two person economy where 2 consumers have CES utility functions: $u^i(x_1,x_2) = (x_1^ρ+x_2^ρ)^{\frac{1}{ρ}}$, $0<ρ<1$  
> and endowments $e^1 = (1,0)$, $e^2 = (0,1)$  
> 1. What changes on the demands if you divide both prices by $p_2$?  
> The new prices would be $p = \frac{p_1}{p_2}$ and $\hat{p}_2 = 1$  
> 2. Using these prices, derive the consumers' income that they will get from selling their endowments.  
> Derive the consumers' excess demand functions.

1. Since the relative prices do not change, the demands do not change. 
2. Demands in relative price: $$\begin{cases} x_1^i = \frac{p^{r-1}}{p^r+1}y^i \\
x_2^i = \frac{1}{p^r+1}y^i\end{cases}$$ 
where $r = \frac{ρ}{ρ-1}$  
Consumer 1's income: $y^1 = p\cdot 1 + 1\cdot 0 = p$  
Therefore, $$\begin{aligned} x_1^1 = \frac{p^{r-1}}{p^r+1}\cdot p = \frac{p^r}{p^r+1} \\ x_2^1 = \frac{1}{p^r+1}\cdot p \end{aligned}$$ 
Excess demand: $\begin{cases} z_1^1 = x_1^1 - 1 \\z_2^1 = x_2^1\end{cases}$  
Consumer 2's income: $y^2 = p\cdot 0 + 1\cdot 1 = 1$  
Therefore, $$\begin{aligned} x_1^2 = \frac{p^{r-1}}{p^r+1}\\ x_2^2 = \frac{1}{p^r+1}\end{aligned}$$ 
Excess demand: $\begin{cases} z_1^2 = x_1^2 \\z_2^2 = x_2^2 - 1\end{cases}$

> PS2.Q3  
> Consider a two person economy where 2 consumers have CES utility functions: $u^i(x_1,x_2) = (x_1^ρ+x_2^ρ)^{\frac{1}{ρ}}$, $0<ρ<1$  
> and endowments $e^1 = (1,0)$, $e^2 = (0,1)$  
> Argue that a Walrasian equilibrium must exist. 

By Walras' law, $$\begin{aligned} p\cdot z_1 + 1\cdot z_2 &= 0 \\
p(x_1^1 - 1 + x_1^2) + 1\cdot (x_2^1 + x_2^2 - 1) &= 0 \\
p\cdot \frac{p^r}{p^r+1} - p + p\cdot\frac{p^{r-1}}{p^r+1} + \frac{1}{p^r+1}\cdot p + \frac{1}{p^r+1} - 1 &= 0 \\
(p+1)\frac{p^r}{p^r+1} + (p+1)\frac{1}{p^r+1} &= p+1 \\
\frac{p^r}{p^r+1} + \frac{1}{p^r+1} &= 1\end{aligned}$$ 
Need to find $p$ s.t. $$\begin{aligned} z_1^1 + z_1^2 &= 0 \\
\frac{p^r}{p^r+1} - 1 + \frac{p^{r-1}}{p^r+1} &= 0\end{aligned}$$ 
Let $f(p) = \frac{p^r}{p^r+1} - 1 + \frac{p^{r-1}}{p^r+1}$ 
Need to prove $f(p)$ has at least one root (omitted, use L'Hopital's rule)

> PS2.Q4  
> Consider a two person economy where 2 consumers have CES utility functions: $u^i(x_1,x_2) = (x_1^ρ+x_2^ρ)^{\frac{1}{ρ}}$, $0<ρ<1$  
> and endowments $e^1 = (1,0)$, $e^2 = (0,1)$  
> Characterize the contract curve for this economy.

For each $\bar{u}\in\big[0,2^{\frac{1}{ρ}}\big]$, bundles on the contract curve satisfy: 
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{x_1^1, x_2^1} u^1 &= \big((x_1^1)^ρ+(x_2^1)^ρ\big)^{\frac{1}{ρ}} \\
s.t. u^2 &= \big((1-x_1^1)^ρ+(1-x_2^1)^ρ\big)^{\frac{1}{ρ}} = \bar{u} \\
\mathcal{L} &= \big((x_1^1)^ρ+(x_2^1)^ρ\big)^{\frac{1}{ρ}} - λ \left(\big((1-x_1^1)^ρ+(1-x_2^1)^ρ\big)^{\frac{1}{ρ}} - \bar{u}\right)\end{aligned}$$ 
FOC: 
$$\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial x_1^1} &= \frac{1}{ρ}\cdot\big((x_1^1)^ρ+(x_2^1)^ρ\big)^{\frac{1}{ρ}-1}\cdot ρ\cdot (x_1^1)^{ρ-1} \\
&\phantom{12} - λ\cdot \frac{1}{ρ}\big((1-x_1^1)^ρ+(1-x_2^1)^ρ\big)^{\frac{1}{ρ}-1}\cdot ρ\cdot(1-x_1^1)^{ρ-1} \\
&= \big((x_1^1)^ρ+(x_2^1)^ρ\big)^{\frac{1}{ρ}-1}\cdot (x_1^1)^{ρ-1} - λ\cdot\big((1-x_1^1)^ρ+(1-x_2^1)^ρ\big)^{\frac{1}{ρ}-1}\cdot(1-x_1^1)^{ρ-1} = 0 \\
\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial x_2^1} &= \big((x_1^1)^ρ+(x_2^1)^ρ\big)^{\frac{1}{ρ}-1}\cdot (x_2^1)^{ρ-1} - λ\cdot\big((1-x_1^1)^ρ+(1-x_2^1)^ρ\big)^{\frac{1}{ρ}-1}\cdot(1-x_2^1)^{ρ-1} = 0\end{aligned}$$ 
$$\begin{aligned} \frac{(x_1^1)^{ρ-1}}{(x_2^1)^{ρ-1}} &= \frac{(1-x_1^1)^{ρ-1}}{(1-x_2^1)^{ρ-1}} \\
\frac{x_1^1}{x_2^1} &= \frac{1-x_1^1}{1-x_2^1}\end{aligned}$$
Therefore, the contract curve is a 45° line

> PS2.Q5  
> Consider a two person economy where 2 consumers have CES utility functions: $u^i(x_1,x_2) = (x_1^ρ+x_2^ρ)^{\frac{1}{ρ}}$, $0<ρ<1$  
> and endowments $e^1 = (1,0)$, $e^2 = (0,1)$  
> Characterize the core for this economy.

Consumer 1 weakly preferes allocations s.t. $$\begin{aligned} \big((x_1^1)^ρ+(x_2^1)^ρ\big)^{\frac{1}{ρ}} &\geq (1^ρ+0^ρ)^{\frac{1}{ρ}} \\ &=1 \\
(x_1^1)^ρ+(x_2^1)^ρ \geq 1 \end{aligned}$$ 
Consumer 2 weakly preferes allocations s.t. $$\begin{aligned} \big((x_1^2)^ρ+(x_2^2)^ρ\big)^{\frac{1}{ρ}} &\geq (0^ρ+1^ρ)^{\frac{1}{ρ}} \\ &=1 \\
(1-x_1^1)^ρ+(1-x_2^1)^ρ \geq 1 \end{aligned}$$ 
The core is the part of contract curve that is inside the lens. 

### Total Welfare (Exchange)

- First Welfare Theorem: every WEA is Pareto efficient
    - Condition: $u^i$ strictly increasing $\implies W(e)\subset C(e)$
- Second Welfare Theorem: for every Pareto efficient allocation $\bar{x}$,  
if the initial endowments have been redistributed to $\bar{x}$, then $\bar{x}$ is a WEA 
    - Conditions:
    - (Assumption 5.1) for all $u^i$
    - $\sum_{\mathcal{I}} e^i \gg 0$
- Corollary: if the initial endowments have been redistributed to $e^*\in F(e)$ s.t. $\bar{p}\cdot e^{*i} = \bar{p}\cdot\bar{x}^i$, then $\bar{x}$ is a WEA for WE $\bar{p}$

> PS3.Q1  
> Consider an exchange economy with two identical consumers  
> Their common utility function is $u^i (x_1, x_2) = x_1^α x_2^{1-α}$ for $0<α<1$  
> Society has 10 units of $x_1$ and 10 units of $x_2$ in all.  
> Find endowments $e^1$ and $e^2$ and Walrasian equilibrium prices that will support as a Walrasian Equilibrium Allocation: the equal-division allocation, giving both consumers the bundle $(5, 5)$

Let price of good 1 be $1$, and price of good 2 be $p = \frac{p_2}{p_1}$  
Consumer 1's problem:  
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{x_1^1,x_2^1} u^1 = (x_1^1)^α(x_2^1)^{1-α} && x_1^1 + p\cdot x_2^1 = e_1^1 + p\cdot e_2^1\end{aligned}$$ 
Set MRS = price ratio:  
$$\begin{aligned} \frac{α\cdot x_2^1}{(1-α)\cdot x_1^1} &= \frac{1}{p} \\
α\cdot x_2^1\cdot p &= (1-α)\cdot x_1^1 \\
x_2^1 &= \frac{(1-α)\cdot x_1^1}{αp}\end{aligned}$$ 
Therefore,
$$\begin{aligned} x_1^1 + p\cdot \frac{(1-α)\cdot x_1^1}{αp} &= e_1^1 + p\cdot e_2^1 \\
\frac{x_1^1}{α} &= e_1^1 + p\cdot e_2^1 \\
x_1^1 &= α(e_1^1 + p\cdot e_2^1) \\
x_2^1 &= \frac{1-α}{p}\cdot(e_1^1 + p\cdot e_2^1)\end{aligned}$$ 
Similarly, for consumer 2: 
$$\begin{aligned} x_1^2 &= α(e_1^2 + p\cdot e_2^2) \\
x_2^2 &= \frac{1-α}{p}\cdot(e_1^2 + p\cdot e_2^2)\end{aligned}$$ 
For an equal-division allocation, we need 
$$\begin{cases} x_1^1 = x_1^2 = 5 \\ x_2^1 = x_2^2 = 5 \end{cases}$$
for all $α$'s, therefore, 
$$\begin{aligned} α &= \frac{1-α}{p} \\ p &= \frac{1-α}{α}\end{aligned}$$ 

The endowments should be s.t. 
$$\begin{cases} αe_1^1 + (1-α)e_2^1) = 5 \\ αe_1^2 + (1-α) e_2^2) = 5\end{cases}$$ 
for all $α$'s, therefore, 
$$\begin{aligned} e_1^1 = e_1^2 = 5 \\ e_2^1 = e_2^2 = 5\end{aligned}$$

## General Equilibrium (Production)

- Economy: $\mathcal{E}=(u^i, e^i, θ^{ij}, Y^j)_{i\in \mathcal{I}, j\in\mathcal{J}}$ 
- Set of firms: $\mathcal{J}\equiv\{1,2,\dots, J\}$ 
    - Production plan: $y^j \in\mathbb{R}^K$, positive element is output, negative elements are input
- Production possibility set: $Y^j$
    - AMT Assumption 5.2:
    - $0\in Y^j$ 
    - Compact
    - Strongly Convex
    - No free production ($y^j\cap\mathbb{R}^K_{+} = 0$)
- Firm's problem: $$Π_j(p) = \max_{y^j} p\cdot y^j$$ 
    - Continuous
    - $Y^j$ is strongly convex $\implies Π_j(p)$ has unique solution in $p\gg 0$
- Profit-maximizing plan: $y^j(p)$
    - Continuous
    - Unique for every $p\in\mathbb{R}^K_{++}$
- Aggregate production: $$Y \equiv \{ y \ | \ y = \sum_{\mathcal{J}} y^j, \ y^j\in Y^j\}$$
    - $Y^j$ satisfies (Assumption 5.2) for all $j\implies Y$ satisfies (Assumption 5.2)
    - $p\cdot\bar{y}\geq p\cdot y$ for all $y\in Y\iff p\cdot\bar{y}^j\geq p\cdot y^j$ for all $y^j\in Y^j$, $j\in\mathcal{J}$

### Production Equilibrium

- Assume all firms are owned by consumers through shares
- Consumer's budget constraint: $$m^i(p) = p\cdot e^i + \underbrace{\sum_{\mathcal{J}} θ^{ij}\cdot Π_j(p)}_{\text{share of profit}}\geq 0$$ 
    - Assumption 5.2 $\implies$ Continuous in $p\in\mathbb{R}^K_{+}$
- Consumer's problem: $$\begin{aligned} \max u^i(x^i) && \text{s.t.} && p\cdot x^i\leq m^i(p)\end{aligned}$$
- Demand: $x^i\big(p, m^i(p)\big)$
    - (Assumption 5.1) + (Assumption 5.2) + $p\in\mathbb{R}^K_{++}\implies$ __Existence + Unique__
    - $m^i(p)$ continuous $\implies$ Continuous in $p\in\mathbb{R}^K_{++}$
- Aggregate Excess Demand for good k: $$z_k(p) = \underbrace{\sum_{\mathcal{I}} x^i_k\big(p, m^i(p)\big)}_{\text{Consumption}} - \underbrace{\sum_{\mathcal{J}} y^j_k(p)}_{\text{Production}} - \underbrace{\sum_{\mathcal{I}} e^i_k}_{\text{Endowment}}$$
    - Aggregate Excess Demand vector: $$z(p) = \big(z_1(p), z_2(p),\dots, z_n(p)\big)$$
    - Net Aggregate Production: $$y + \sum_{\mathcal{I}} e^i$$
- Walrasian Equilibrium: $p^*\in\mathbb{R}^K_{++}$ s.t. $z(p^*) = 0$ 
    - Conditions:
    - Assumption 5.1
    - Assumption 5.2
    - Net Aggregate Production $\in\mathbb{R}^K_{++}$ for some $y\in\sum_{\mathcal{J}} Y^j$

> PS3.Q2, Example 5.2  
> Suppose Robinson is endowed with zero units of the consumption good $y$, and 24 hours of time $h$, so $e = (24,0)$.  
> Suppose his preferences are represented by the utility function $u(h,y) = h\cdot y$.  
> Production possibilities are $Y = \big\{ (-h,y) \ | \ 0\leq h\leq b, 0\leq y\leq\sqrt{h}\big\}$, where $b$ is some large positive number.  
> 1. Find relative prices that clear the consumption and leisure markets simultaneously.  

Let $p_y\to p$ denote the price of good y, and $p_h\to w$ denote the price of $h$  
The firm does not waste input, so it will choose $y = \sqrt{h}$  
The firm's problem: 
$$\begin{aligned} \max_{y,h} π(w,p) &= p\cdot y - w\cdot h \\ &= p\cdot\sqrt{h} - w\cdot h\end{aligned}$$ 
FOC: 
$$\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial π(w,p)}{\partial h} &= \frac{1}{2}p\cdot h^{-\frac{1}{2}} - w = 0 \\
h^f &= \frac{p^2}{4w^2} \\
y^f &= \frac{p}{2w}\end{aligned}$$ 
Profit function: $$\begin{aligned} π(w,p) &= p\cdot y - w\cdot h \\ &= \frac{p^2}{4w}\end{aligned}$$

The consumer's budget constraint: $$m^i(w,p) =  \underbrace{w\cdot 24}_{\text{Endowment}} + π(w,p) \geq p\cdot y + \underbrace{w\cdot h}_{\text{Cost of leisure}}$$
The consumer's problem (with no waste): 
$$\begin{aligned} \max_{h,y} u(h,y) = h\cdot y && \text{s.t.} && w\cdot 24 + π(w,p) = p\cdot y\end{aligned}$$ 
Set MRS = price ratio: 
$$\begin{aligned} \frac{y}{h} &= \frac{w}{p} \\ p\cdot y &= w\cdot h\end{aligned}$$ 
Therefore, 
$$\begin{aligned} p\cdot y = w\cdot h &= \frac{1}{2}\big(w\cdot 24 + π(w,p)\big) \\ 
y^c &= \frac{12w}{p} + \frac{1}{2p}π(w,p) \\
h^c &= 12 + \frac{1}{2w}π(w,p)\end{aligned}$$ 

Clear the market: $\begin{cases} y^c = y^f \\ h^c + h^f = 24\end{cases}$  
$$\begin{aligned} \frac{12w}{p} + \frac{1}{2p}π(w,p) &= \frac{p}{2w} \\
12 + \frac{1}{2w}π(w,p) + \frac{p^2}{4w^2} &= 24\end{aligned}$$ 
$\implies p^2 = 32w^2$  
Set $p^* = 1$, $w^* = \frac{1}{\sqrt{32}}$ 

> PS3.Q2  
> Suppose Robinson is endowed with zero units of the consumption good $y$, and 24 hours of time $h$, so $e = (24,0)$.  
> Suppose his preferences are represented by the utility function $u(h,y) = h\cdot y$.  
> Production possibilities are $Y = \big\{ (-h,y) \ | \ 0\leq h\leq b, 0\leq y\leq\sqrt{h}\big\}$, where $b$ is some large positive number.  
> 2. Calculate the equilibirum consumption and production plans.  
> 3. How many hours a day does the consumer work?

2. When $p^* = 1$, $w^* = \frac{1}{\sqrt{32}}$,  
Production plan: $$\begin{aligned} h^f &= \frac{p^2}{4w^2} \\ &= \frac{1}{4w^2} = 8 \\
y^f &= \frac{p}{2w} \\ &= \frac{1}{2\cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{32}}} = 2\sqrt{2}\end{aligned}$$ 
Consumption: $y^c = y^f = 2\sqrt{2}$  
3. $h^c = 24 - h^f = 16$

### Total Welfare (Production)

AMT P234

- First Welfare Theorem: every WEA is Pareto efficient
    - Condition: $u^i$ strictly increasing $\implies W(e)\subset C(e)$
- Second Welfare Theorem: for every Pareto efficient allocation $\bar{x},\bar{y}$,  
exists (consumer) income transfers $T_1,\dots,T_I$, $\sum_{\mathcal{I}} T_i = 0$, and WE $\bar{p}$  
s.t. $\bar{x},\bar{y}$ is a WEA 
    - Conditions: 
    - (Assumption 5.1) for all $u^i$ 
    - (Assumption 5.2) for all $Y^j$ 
    - Net Aggregate Production $\in\mathbb{R}^K_{++}$

## Externality (Perfect Information)

MWG 11.A, slide 16

- The well-being of a consumer or the production possibilities of a firm  
is directly affected by the action of another agent in the society
    - Negative / Positive

### Bilateral Externality

- Consumers: $i = 1, 2$ 
- Wealth: $w^i$
- Utility function: $u^i( x_1^i, x_2^i,\dots,x_L^i, h)$
    - $h\in\mathbb{R}_+$ is an action taken by consumer 1
    - Externality: assume $\frac{\partial u^2}{\partial h}\neq 0$
- Derived (Indirect) Utility Function:  
$$\begin{aligned}v^i(p,w^i,h) = \max_{x^i} u^i(x^i,h) && \text{s.t.} && p\cdot x^i\leq w^i\end{aligned}$$
    - assume: $u^i$ is quasi-linear in commodity 1
    $$\begin{aligned}u^i(x^i,h) &= g^i(x_{-1}^i,h) + x_1^i \\
    v^i(p,w^i,h) &= \underbrace{g^i\big(x_{-1}^{i*}(p,h),h\big) - p\cdot x_1^{i*}(p,h)} + w^i \\
    &= \overbrace{φ^i(p,h)} + w^i \\
    &= φ^i(h) + w^i\end{aligned}$$
    - assume: $φ^i(h)$ is twice differentiable, $φ^{i\prime\prime} (\cdot)<0$ (concave)
- Inefficiency:  
Pareto Optimal:  
$$\begin{aligned} \max_{h\geq 0} && φ^1(h) &+ φ^2(h) \\
FOC && φ^{1\prime}(h^o) &= - φ^{2\prime}(h^o)\end{aligned}$$ 
Competitive Outcome:  
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{h\geq 0} && φ^1(h)& \\
FOC && φ^{1\prime}(h^*) &= 0 \\\end{aligned}$$
assume Negative externality,
$$\begin{aligned}φ^{2\prime}(h) &< 0 \\
φ^{1\prime}(h^o) &= - φ^{2\prime}(h^o) > 0 \\
h^o &< h^*\end{aligned}$$

### Quota 

- Set $h\leq h^o$

### Taxation

- Pigouvian Taxation Rate: $t_h = - φ^{2\prime}(h^o)$
- Competitive Outcome:  
$$\begin{aligned} \max_{h\geq 0} && φ^1(h) - t_h\cdot h& \\
FOC && φ^{1\prime}(h^t) - t_h &= 0 \\
&& φ^{1\prime}(h^t) &= t_h \\
&& &= - φ^{2\prime}(h^o) \\
&& h^t &= h^o\end{aligned}$$ 

### Bargain (Property Right)

- When consumer 2 has the property right, their problem:  
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{h\geq 0, T} && φ^2(h) + T && \text{s.t.} && \underbrace{φ^1(h) - T \geq φ^1(0)}_{\text{Compatibility Constraint}}\end{aligned}$$
set the constraint to equality,  
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{h\geq 0} && φ^2(h) + φ^1(h) - φ^1(0)& \\
FOC && φ^{2\prime}(h^b) + φ^{1\prime}(h^b) &= 0 \\
&& h^b &= h^o\end{aligned}$$ 
    - Consumer 1 pays $T$ to consumer 2, and enjoys $h^{b} = h^o$
- When consumer 1 has the property right, consumer 2's problem:  
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{h\geq 0, T} && φ^2(h) + T && \text{s.t.} && \underbrace{φ^1(h) - T \geq φ^1(h^*)}_{\text{Compatibility Constraint}}\end{aligned}$$
set the constraint to equality,  
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{h\geq 0} && φ^2(h) + φ^1(h) - φ^1(h^*)& \\
FOC && φ^{2\prime}(h^b) + φ^{1\prime}(h^{**}) &= 0 \\
&& h^b &= h^o\end{aligned}$$ 
    - Consumer 1 receives $T$ from consumer 2, and enjoys $h^{**} = h^o$
- Coase's Theorem: bargaining leads to an efficient outcome no matter how property rights are allocated

### Multilateral Externality

MWG 11.D, slide 17

- $I$ consumers, $J$ firms
- Firm's Derived Utility Function: $π^j(h^j)$
    - assume: Concave, $π^{j\prime\prime}(\cdot) < 0$
- Consumer's Derived Utility Function: $φ^i(\tilde{h}^j)$
    - assume:
    - Negative Externality: $φ^{i\prime}(\cdot) < 0$
    - Concave:  $φ^{i\prime\prime}(\cdot) < 0$
    - Non-Depletable: $\tilde{h}^j =\sum_J h^j$
- Pareto Iptimal: 
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{h^1,\dots,h^J\geq 0} && \underbrace{\sum_I φ^i\big(\sum_J h^j\big)}_{\text{Consumers}} + \underbrace{\sum_J π^j(h^j)}_{\text{Firms}}& \\
FOC && \sum_I φ^{i\prime}\big(\sum_J h^{jo}\big) + π^{j\prime}(h^{jo}) &= 0 \\
&& \sum_I φ^{i\prime}\big(\sum_J h^{jo}\big) &= - π^{j\prime}(h^{jo})\end{aligned}$$
- Without government intervention, the competitive outcome of non-depletable externality acts like [public goods](#private-provision)

### Taxation

- Tax Rate: $t_h = -\sum_I φ^{i\prime}\big(\sum_J h^{jo}\big)$
- Competitive Outcome: 
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{h^j} && π^j(h^j) - t_h\cdot h^j& \\
FOC && π^{j\prime}(h^{jt}) - t_h &= 0 \\
&& π^{j\prime}(h^{jt}) &= t_h \\
&& &= -\sum_I φ^{i\prime}\big(\sum_J h^{jo}\big) \\
&& &= π^{j\prime}(h^{jo}) \\
&& h^{jt} &= h^{jo}\end{aligned}$$

## Externality (Asymmetric Information)

MWG 11.E, slide 17 P6

- Assume bilateral externality
- Firm's Derived Utility Function: $π(h, θ)$
    - assume: twice-differentiable, $π''(\cdot) < 0$
- Consumer's Derived Utility Function: $φ(h, η)$
    - assume:
    - Negative Externality: $φ'(\cdot) < 0$
    - Concave: $φ''(\cdot) < 0$

### Bargain

- Assume two levels of externality: 0 and $\bar{h}$
    - $h = 0$ when no agreements exist (property rights on the consumer)
    - $h = \bar{h}$ when $b > c$
- Firm's Profit: 
$$b(θ) = π(\bar{h}, θ) - π(0, θ)$$
    - Probability Density Function of $θ$: $g(b)$
    - Cumulative Distribution Function: $G(b)$
- Consumer's Cost: 
$$c(η) = φ(0, η) - φ(\bar{h}, η)$$
    - Probability Density Function of $η$: $f(c)$
    - Cumulative Distribution Function: $F(c)$
- Consumer's Problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_T && \underbrace{\big(1 - \overbrace{G(T)}^{Pr(b\leq T)}\big)}_{Pr(b>T)>0}\times \underbrace{(T - c)}_{\text{Consumer's net benefit}}& \\
\end{aligned}$$
    - $T^b > c$
    - When $T^b > b > c$, firm will not agree, $h = 0$, not Pareto optimal

FOC && \big(1 - G(T)\big)\cdot 1 + \big(-g(t)\big)\cdot (T - c) &= 0 \\
&& 1 - G(T) - g(t)\cdot (T - c) &= 0
-->

### Government Intervention

- Pareto Optimal: 
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{h} && π(h, θ) + φ(h, η)& \\
FOC && π'(h^o, θ) + φ'(h^o, η) &= 0 \\
&& π'(h^o, θ) &= - φ'(h^o, η)\end{aligned}$$

![MWG Figure 11.E.1](/post-img/notes-micro--externality-asy-info-gov.png)

### Quota

- Set $h\leq \hat{h}$ (government has no infomation about $h^o$)
- Firm's Problem: 
$$\begin{aligned}\max_h && π(h, θ)& && \text{s.t.} && h\leq \hat{h}\end{aligned}$$
    - let the solution be $h^q(\hat{h}, θ)$

![MWG Figure 11.E.2](/post-img/notes-micro--externality-asy-info-quota.png)

### Taxation

- Tax Rate: $t$
- Firm's Problem: 
$$\begin{aligned}\max_h && π(h, θ) - t\cdot h& \\
FOC && π(h^t, θ) - t &= 0 \\
&& h^t &= h^t(t,θ)\end{aligned}$$

![MWG Figure 11.E.3](/post-img/notes-micro--externality-asy-info-tax.png)

> MWG Exercise 11.E.1  
> Suppose a firm's profit function is $$π(h,θ) = -\frac{1}{2b}(β + θ - bh)^2$$ 
> and a consumer's utility function is $$φ(h,η) = -\frac{1}{2c}(γ + η - ch)^2$$ 
> $β,b,c > 0$ and $γ<0$ are known, $E[θ] = E[η] = 0$, $E[θ^2] = σ_θ^2$, $E[η^2] = σ_η^2$, $E[θ\cdot η] = 0$  
> 1. Identify the best quota $\hat{h}^*$ for a planner who wants to maximize the expected value of aggregate surplus  
> 2. Identify the best tax $t^*$ for this same planner  
> 3. Compare the two instruments: Which is better and when?

1. The social planner's problem:  
$$\begin{aligned}\max_h && &\phantom{ggg} E[π(h,θ)] + E[φ(h,η)] \\
&& &= -\frac{1}{2b}(β + θ - bh)^2 -\frac{1}{2c}(γ + η - ch)^2 \\
FOC && &\phantom{ggg}\frac{\partial}{\partial h}E\Big[ -\frac{1}{2b}(β + θ - bh)^2 -\frac{1}{2c}(γ + η - ch)^2\Big] \\
&& &= E\Big[ -\frac{1}{b}(b^2h - βb - θb) - \frac{1}{c}(c^2h - γc - ηc) \Big] \\
&& &= E[- bh + β + θ - ch + γ + η] \\
&& &= (- b - c) h + β + γ = 0 \\
&& \hat{h}^* &= \frac{β + γ}{b + c}\end{aligned}$$ 
2. Under a tax rate of $t$, the firm's problem:  
$$\begin{aligned}\max_h && -\frac{1}{2b}(β + θ - bh)^2 - th& \\
FOC && -bh + β + θ - t &= 0 \\
&& h(t) &= \frac{β + θ - t}{b}\end{aligned}$$ 
The social planner's problem:  
$$\begin{aligned}\max_t && &\phantom{ggg} E[π(h,θ)] + E[φ(h,η)] \\
&& &= -\frac{1}{2b}\big(β + θ - bh(t)\big)^2 -\frac{1}{2c}\big(γ + η - ch(t)\big)^2 \\
FOC && &\phantom{ggg}\frac{\partial}{\partial t}E\Big[ -\frac{1}{2b}\big(β + θ - bh(t)\big)^2 -\frac{1}{2c}\big(γ + η - ch(t)\big)^2 \Big] \\
&& &= \frac{\partial}{\partial h}E\Big[ -\frac{1}{2b}(β + θ - bh)^2 -\frac{1}{2c}(γ + η - ch)^2\Big]\cdot\frac{\partial h(t)}{\partial t} \\
&& &= E\big[(- b - c)\cdot h(t) + β + γ\big]\cdot\frac{\partial h(t)}{\partial t} \\
&& &= E\Big[(- b - c)\cdot\frac{β + θ - t}{b} + β + γ\Big]\cdot\frac{-1}{b} \\
&& &= E\Big[(b + c)\cdot\frac{β + θ - t}{b^2} - \frac{β}{b} - \frac{γ}{b}\Big] \\
&& &= (b + c)\cdot\frac{β - t}{b^2} - \frac{β}{b} - \frac{γ}{b} = 0 \\
&& t^* &= \frac{cβ - bγ}{b+c}\end{aligned}$$

## Public Goods

MWG 11.C

- $I$ consumers, $L$ commodities, $1$ public good
- Derived (Indirect) Utility Function for $q$ units of public good  
$$v^i = φ^i(q) + w^i$$
    - assume: $φ^{i\prime} (\cdot)>0$
- Pareto Optimal: 
$$\begin{aligned} \max_{q\geq 0} && \sum_I φ^i(q) - c(q)& \\
FOC && \sum_I φ^{i\prime}(q^o) - c'(q^o) &= 0 \\
&& \sum_I φ^{i\prime}(q^o) &= c'(q^o)\end{aligned}$$
    - assume: 
    - $c^{\prime} (\cdot)>0$
    - Convex: $c'' (\cdot)>0$ for all $q\geq 0$

### Private Provision

- Consumer i's problem: 
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{q^i\geq 0} && φ^i(q^i + \sum_L x_l^*) - p^*\cdot q^i& \\
FOC && φ^{i\prime}(q^{i*} + \sum_L x_l^*) - p^* &= 0 \\
&& φ^{i\prime}(q^{i*} + \sum_L x_l^*) &= p^*\end{aligned}$$ 
take $q^{-i*}$ as constant, let $q^d = \sum_I q^{i*}$,  
$$φ^{i\prime}(q^d) = p^*$$ 
- Firm's problem: 
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{q\geq 0} && p^*\cdot q- c(q)& \\
FOC && p^* - c'(q^s) &= 0 \\ 
&& p^* &= c'(q^s)\end{aligned}$$
- Competitive Equilibrium: 
$$\begin{aligned} q^s &= q^d \\
φ^{i\prime}(q^*) &= c'(q^*) \\
c'(q^*) &< c'(q^o) \\
q^* &< q^o\end{aligned}$$

### Subsidy

- Subsidy Rate: $s^i = φ^{-i\prime}(q^o)$
- Consumer i's problem:  
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{q^i\geq 0} && φ^i(q^i + \sum_L x_l^*) - p^{**}\cdot q^i + s^i\cdot q^i& \\
FOC && φ^{i\prime}(q^i + \sum_L x_l^*) - p^{**} + s^i &= 0 \\
&& φ^{i\prime}(q^i + \sum_L x_l^*) + s^i &= p^{**}\end{aligned}$$ 
let $q^{d*} = \sum_I q^{i*}$,  
$$\begin{aligned} φ^{i\prime}(q^{d*}) + s^i &= p^{**} \\
φ^{i\prime}(q^{d*}) + φ^{-i\prime}(q^o) &= p^{**} \\\end{aligned}$$
consider firm's problem, 
$$\begin{aligned}φ^{i\prime}(q^{d*}) + φ^{-i\prime}(q^o) &= c'(p^{**}) \\
q^{d*} &= q^o\end{aligned}$$
